O. D• K.
To the eight men who were initiated into Omicron Delta Kappa Honorary Fraternity yesterday we tender
our most sincere congratulations.
These men, four of whom are juniors
and who will return next fall to form
the nucleus of the organization for the
coming acamedic term, have obtained
the most coveted honor on the campus
and we hope that they, by their work
and actions, will keep the fraternity
of the same high level, that it has
been based on during its years of existence at the Hopkins.
You have fought a good fight and
won a great victory.
Dr. Swartz's Retirement
In June, Dr. Charles K. Swartz, for
the past twenty-seven years an instructor in geology, a man respected and
beloved by both faculty and student
body, is to retire from active duties as
collegiate professor at the Johns Hopkins University.
Indeed, it will be with a touch of
regret that we will soon bid farewell
to this gray-haired gentleman who
bears no other traces of seventy years
of active and hard work; that we
must, very shortly, lose such an outstanding personality from the faculty.
Yet when the actual day of his retirement approaches it will not be a
sad occasion, truly, for we will not be
losing a very principal man from our
social and educational circles; we will
not be weeping over his grave. We
will be, on the contrary, really congratulating him upon the triumphant
results of his services as a teacher at
the Johns Hopkins. He has good
health, a virile body and mind. He has
hosts of friends, a family, and work
to which he is devoted. He shall have
the right to look forward, as we hope
and expect, to the long enjoyment as
a professor emeritus.
Indubitably, it is undeniable that
Dr. Swartz has been one of the out-

standing instructors at the Hopkins
and that no member of the faculty has
been held in greater esteem and affection by his students than he. One of
the most popular and best liked professors at Homewood, he is to leave
us in less than two months, after having reached the maximum age limitation for the faculty members, to continue his geological investigations and
and writings in the fields in which he
is most interested.
As seen in the news story elsewhere
in this paper today, Dr. E. B. Mathews, professor of minerology and
petrography, highly commends Dr.
Swartz. Dr. Mathews even goes so far
as to declare that it is a difficult task
to replace him with a man of his equal
in every respect.,That in itself is a
high commendation from one who
has intimately known the retiring collegiate professor throughout his college, university, and teaching careers.
Devoted to geology and teaching,
Dr. Swartz has proved himself an almost inimitable instructor in that field
of study at the Hopkins or, perhaps,
elsewhere. His boyhood desire to become a geology teacher has been happily realized, we believe. As a faculty
member he has held an interest in the
elevation, from all angles, of the University.
We sincerely hope that in future
years Dr. Swartz will always look
back upon his work here, following
his retirement, as one of the "firighest
pictures in memory's collection."
Rather prematurely, to this "grand
old man of the campus" we wish all
happiness and prosperity and hope for
his continued interest in the Johns
Hopkins University—her progress,
her students, her faculty—as he has
manifested during his twenty-seven
years' services as a splendid teacher,
a worthy friend, a devoted scholar,
and a gentleman.
To the two men who will carry on
the work of Dr. Swartz, Dr. Mark
Secrist and Dr. J. D H Donnay, we
express our hope for good luck and
success.
H. L.

To the eight men who were initiated into Omicron Delta Kappa Honorary Fraternity yesterday we tender
our most sincere congratulations.
These men, four of whom are juniors
and who will return next fall to form
the nucleus of the organization for the
coming acamedic term, have obtained
the most coveted honor on the campus
and we hope that they, by their work
and actions, will keep the fraternity
of the same high level, that it has
been based on during its years of existence at the Hopkins.
You have fought a good fight and
won a great victory.
Dr. Swartz's Retirement
In June, Dr. Charles K. Swartz, for
the past twenty-seven years an instructor in geology, a man respected and
beloved by both faculty and student
body, is to retire from active duties as
collegiate professor at the Johns Hopkins University.
Indeed, it will be with a touch of
regret that we will soon bid farewell
to this gray-haired gentleman who
bears no other traces of seventy years
of active and hard work; that we
must, very shortly, lose such an outstanding personality from the faculty.
Yet when the actual day of his retirement approaches it will not be a
sad occasion, truly, for we will not be
losing a very principal man from our
social and educational circles; we will
not be weeping over his grave. We
will be, on the contrary, really congratulating him upon the triumphant
results of his services as a teacher at
the Johns Hopkins. He has good
health, a virile body and mind. He has
hosts of friends, a family, and work
to which he is devoted. He shall have
the right to look forward, as we hope
and expect, to the long enjoyment as
a professor emeritus.
Indubitably, it is undeniable that
Dr. Swartz has been one of the out-

standing instructors at the Hopkins
and that no member of the faculty has
been held in greater esteem and affection by his students than he. One of
the most popular and best liked professors at Homewood, he is to leave
us in less than two months, after having reached the maximum age limitation for the faculty members, to continue his geological investigations and
and writings in the fields in which he
is most interested.
As seen in the news story elsewhere
in this paper today, Dr. E. B. Mathews, professor of minerology and
petrography, highly commends Dr.
Swartz. Dr. Mathews even goes so far
as to declare that it is a difficult task
to replace him with a man of his equal
in every respect.,That in itself is a
high commendation from one who
has intimately known the retiring collegiate professor throughout his college, university, and teaching careers.
Devoted to geology and teaching,
Dr. Swartz has proved himself an almost inimitable instructor in that field
of study at the Hopkins or, perhaps,
elsewhere. His boyhood desire to become a geology teacher has been happily realized, we believe. As a faculty
member he has held an interest in the
elevation, from all angles, of the University.
We sincerely hope that in future
years Dr. Swartz will always look
back upon his work here, following
his retirement, as one of the "firighest
pictures in memory's collection."
Rather prematurely, to this "grand
old man of the campus" we wish all
happiness and prosperity and hope for
his continued interest in the Johns
Hopkins University—her progress,
her students, her faculty—as he has
manifested during his twenty-seven
years' services as a splendid teacher,
a worthy friend, a devoted scholar,
and a gentleman.
To the two men who will carry on
the work of Dr. Swartz, Dr. Mark
Secrist and Dr. J. D H Donnay, we
express our hope for good luck and
success.
H. L.
